qas.question: What type of complexes does uranium(VI) form in nature?
The presence of what substance at alkaline pH makes it difficult to precipitate uranium as phosphate?
What is BSAR-1 a strain of?
What type of complexes does uranium(V) form in nature?
What type of complexes does uranium(VI) not form in nature?
The presence of what substance at alkaline pH makes it easy to precipitate uranium as phosphate?
What is BSAR-2 a strain of?
What is BSAR-1 not a strain of?

context: In nature, uranium(VI) forms highly soluble <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0>carbonate<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> complexes at alkaline pH. This leads to an increase in mobility and availability of uranium to groundwater and soil from nuclear wastes which leads to health hazards. However, it is difficult to precipitate uranium as phosphate in the presence of excess <a1_0><b5_0>carbonate<b5_0/><a1_0/> at alkaline pH. A <a2_0><b6_0><b7_0>Sphingomonas sp.<b7_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/> strain BSAR-1 has been found to express a high activity alkaline phosphatase (PhoK) that has been applied for bioprecipitation of uranium as uranyl phosphate species from alkaline solutions. The precipitation ability was enhanced by overexpressing PhoK protein in E. coli.
